results.title: Review: ‘The Watering Hole’ Can’t Quite Quench a Thirst
results.abstract: The collaborative project conceived by Lynn Nottage is too heterogeneous and muddled to rally around one clear theme or concept.

multimedia.caption: The most traditional theater piece, “Spray Cap,” has one of the few designs that actually work in “The Watering Hole” at Pershing Square Signature Center.

results.title: Review: In ‘Enemy of the People,’ Water and Democracy Are Poisoned
results.abstract: Ann Dowd stars in a contemporary rewrite of Ibsen’s play that forces a community, played by the audience, to make a series of fateful choices.

results.title: ‘Seven Deadly Sins’ Review: Pride and Pole Dancing Behind Glass
results.abstract: This array of short plays has viewers in headphones wandering the meatpacking district for stylish, but shallow, theatrical thrills.

multimedia.caption: Donna Carnow pole dances while Cynthia Nixon voices her thoughts in Bess Wohl’s play “Lust.”

results.title: Springsteen on Broadway: Showing Us How Many Lives We Contain
results.abstract: Two critics on the show’s return — a turning point in live theater and another stage in the rock star’s lifelong evolution.
results.byline: By Jesse Green and Lindsay Zoladz

multimedia.caption: Bruce Springsteen, whose autobiographical show reopened Broadway, at the St. James Theater last Saturday. The singer is “cracking open his songs,” Jesse Green writes, “cracking open himself.”

results.title: The $30 Million Founding Father: How ‘Hamilton’ Got Federal Aid
results.abstract: The megahit had five separate productions around the nation, and with each applying for $10 million in pandemic relief to help get back onstage, the tally could reach $50 million.

multimedia.caption: “Hamilton” qualified for millions under the federal Shuttered Venue Operators Grant program to help its five productions reopen. Its closed Broadway theater, above, was desolate one evening last fall at a time it would normally have been packed with patrons.
multimedia.copyright: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

results.title: Yale Drama Goes Tuition-Free With $150 Million Gift From David Geffen
results.abstract: Starting in August, the drama school plans to eliminate tuition for returning and future students, removing a barrier to entry for low-income students and those worried about debt.

multimedia.caption: The $150 million gift will allow Yale School of Drama to stop charging tuition.

results.title: The Boss Is Back on Broadway. The Workers Are Coming Back, Too.
results.abstract: Broadway took its first steps back with the return of Bruce Springsteen’s show, and no one is happier than Jim Barry, an usher at the St. James Theater for 20 years.

results.abstract: James Ijames’s amusingly cynical and eclectic new play, “The Most Spectacularly Lamentable Trial of Miz Martha Washington,” is at the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival through July 30.

results.abstract: Frank Winters’s play, about two astronauts in lockdown after a mission, uneasily grafts tropes borrowed from hard sci-fi and odd-couple comedy.

results.abstract: One would think that everyone involved in the parody series “Schmigadoon!” was in love with the sometimes hokey, sometimes magical musical genre. Not quite.

results.title: For This Spanish Provocateur, Each Performance Is About Survival
results.abstract: Angélica Liddell says she doesn’t care about looking good onstage. Instead, her visceral works give her catharsis that she says keeps her alive.

results.title: China’s Communist Party Turns 100. Cue the (State-Approved) Music.
results.abstract: A wave of nationalistic music, theater and dance is sweeping China, part of Beijing’s efforts to improve the party’s image and strengthen political loyalty.

results.title: How to Undress Someone Quickly
results.abstract: Don’t start frantically grabbing at someone’s garments; trust is key. Let the person you’re disrobing do some of the work.

results.title: On the Scene: ‘Springsteen on Broadway’ 🎸
results.abstract: On Saturday night, New York City reached a milestone with “Springsteen on Broadway,” the first full-length event for a paying audience on Broadway since March 12, 2020.

results.title: Bruce Springsteen Reopens Broadway, Ushering In Theater’s Return
results.abstract: On Saturday, “Springsteen on Broadway” became the first full-length show to take the stage since the Covid-19 pandemic forced performances to shut down in March 2020.

multimedia.caption: Bruce Springsteen in “Springsteen on Broadway” at the St. James Theater on Saturday night. There will be additional performances of the show through Sept. 4.
